sn1.27:1.1: The “stream” (here sara, otherwise sota) is usually explained as craving (SN 41.5:5.10, Iti 109:3.3). Or else it could be the “stream of lives” (bhavasota) as in the next sutta (SN 1.28:2.2).
sn1.27:1.2: The “cycle” of transmigration (saṁsāra) through endless rebirths (see DN 15:22.6, MN 22:42.2). | The “streams” and the “cycle” also occur together in Ud 7.2:4.1.
sn1.27:2.2: The commentary says this is Nibbāna. | A gādha is a “ford” across a river (Rig Veda 7.60.7, 7.97.8, 10.106.9; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.5.2a), a safe path on which one has a “footing” to cross the water. In this verse, the verb form gādhati means to be “established” (patiṭṭhita) like a seed in soil, or a beam of light on a floor, or consciousness in name and form.
sn1.27:2.6: Passages such as Snp 5.2:6.3, DN 15:22.6 and [dn11:85.26}() say that consciousness ceases at this point, too.
